awd_titl_txt: Feature-Based Data Assimilation and Uncertainty Quantification for Complex Systems in Science and Engineering
awd_abstract_narration:
The basic idea of data assimilation is to update a computational model with information from sparse and noisy data so that the updated model can be used for predictions. Data assimilation is at the core of computational geophysics, most notably in numerical weather prediction, oceanography, and geomagnetism, and is used widely in engineering applications, ranging from robotics to reservoir modeling. In the usual approach one attempts to refine a computational model such that its outputs match data. However, matching model outputs directly to data is often unnecessary or even undesirable. In this project, data assimilation is extended so that computational models can be updated based on features in the data, rather than the raw data themselves. The feature approach reduces an intrinsic dimension and is applicable to large scale problems in geosciences and engineering, with specific applications in geomagnetic dipole reversals, cloud modeling, and uncertainty quantification for solar cells.

The primary technical aim of this project is to extend data assimilation such that computational models can be calibrated against features observed in the data, rather than the raw data. This can be achieved within a Bayesian framework by replacing the data with a suitable low-dimensional feature, computed from the data. The resulting feature-based likelihood can be used to assimilate selected aspects of fine-scale data into coarse, low-dimensional models. More generally, the use of features reduces the dimension of the likelihood, which in turn reduces the computational requirements of feature-based data assimilation by Monte Carlo methods. The mathematical foundations of the feature-based approach will be explored by rigorous analysis. New computational methods for feature-based data assimilation will be created, which combine machine learning techniques with Monte Carlo sampling. The efficiency of these methods will be assessed by interdisciplinary collaboration with scientists in geosciences and engineering in three specific applications. Specifically, feature-based data assimilation algorithms will be developed for the study of superchrons of Earth's magnetic dipole field, to determine the geophysical relevance of low-dimensional cloud models, and for uncertainty quantification of thin-film polymeric reflectors for solar power generation. These applications will collaboratively connect scientists (faculty, postdocs and students) across several disciplines (geosciences, engineering, mathematics). Undergraduate and graduate students at the University of Arizona will be trained as part of the project and will aid in producing and disseminating key results. The research activities will be accompanied by an outreach plan, implemented as part of the G-Teams program within the Department of Mathematics at the University of Arizona. A central outreach theme is to demonstrate, for K-12 teachers and their students, mathematics "in action" by applying mathematical concepts to problems relevant to our society.

por.por_cntn:
Suppose you want to use a numerical model to make a forecast for tomorrow's weather. If your model predicts rain, but you wake up to sunshine, then you should incorporate this observation into your numerical model for the next forecast. This is an example of "Bayesian inference", where one uses observations, or data, to improve numerical models. Bayesian inference is widely used in Engineering and Earth science. For example, Bayesian inference problems I have worked on occur in

  • predicting reversals of Earth's axial magnetic dipole field;
  • modeling the formation of stratocumulus clouds over warm oceans;
  • modeling the propagation of flame fronts;
  • predicting how much sunlight hits a particular area of Tucson, Arizona, within the next 30 minutes.

The mathematical, numerical and computational foundations of Bayesian inference are well-studied if the numerical model is an adequate representation of the underlying physical process. For example, in numerical weather prediction, the numerical model generates an atmospheric state that can be directly compared with observations of the atmosphere. 

This project established the mathemmatical, conceptual and computational foundations for connecting mathematical models to selected aspects of data. We call this technique "feature-based data assimilation", because we first extract features from the data and then perform Bayesian inference based on the extracted features. This approach is required in two important scenarios.

  1. When a model is representative of only certain aspects of a complex process.
  2. When the data are redundant.

In both cases, the feature-based approach leads to a dimension reduction of the data, making the computations down the line more effective and faster to perform.

In particular case 1, has impactful applications in Earth science, where we can use feature-based data assimilation to calibrate simplified models to observations of our planet.

In cloud microphysics, for example, we can use predator-prey type models, that represent rain as a predator of clouds, to represent growth and decay of stratocumulus clouds over warm oceans. The feature-based data assimilation enables us to use such simplified models in a quantitative fashion -- while up to now, these models were only useful as qualitative representations. Since stratocumulus clouds cover roughly one fifth of the Earth's surface, they are important for climate studies in particular and Atmospheric science in general. Our tools of feature-based data assimilation pave the way for using predator-prey type models as a part of the parametrization of stratocumulus within important climate simulations. This work was done in collaboration with cloud modelers at NOAA.

In another application, we use feature based data assimilation to study the Earth's axial magnetic dipole field over vastly different time scales. Over milions of years, the dipole field has the striking characteristic that it reverses polarity -- the magnetic north pole becomes the magnetic south pole and vice versa. Such reversals have occured over the history of our planet, with the last reversal having occured 781,000 years ago. Over time-scales of hundreds of millions of years, the rate with which reversals occur changes. For example, the reversal rate over the past 30 Myr is about 4 reversals per Myr, but 50-100 Myrs ago, much fewer reversals occured. The reversal rate may be affected by conditions of the chaotic flow of liquid metal at the Earth's core and the feature-based data assimilation has allowed us to study changes in reversal rates of our planet's dipole field.

Together with Earth scientists at UC Berkeley, I have used feature-based data assimilation to construct a comprehensive model of Earth's axial dipole field over thousdands to millions of years. In this context, the feature-based approch has enabled us to use a diverse set of data sources that have previously been treated separately. 

This project has supported one graduate student for three years and a total of three undergraduate students. The graduate student is expected to graduate in Spring 2020. Two of the undergraduates have graduated and one of them will graduate this fall. The students and I have given numerous talks, posters and presentations at Universities, National Labs and conferences accross the US and worldwide.

Together with collaborators and graduate and undergraduate students I have published 15 journal articles during the course of this project.

I gave  a public lecture in the "Everything is math" lecture serious in which I emphasized how important it is to realize the limitations of a prediction. I held a Tucson math teacher circle, where I spent the evening with High School teachers from the Tucson Unified School district, who are interested to sharpen their mathematical tools. We spent the evening using mathematical models for describing the physics of biking. Being an applied mathematician this also included performing an experiment. 

The project also allowed me to participate in the Outreach scholar program, where graduate students showcase mathematics in action in high schools.
